TypeSignature.Value: .class nested protected auto ansi beforefieldinit DataGridView/DataGridViewAccessibleObject extends System.Windows.Forms.Control/ControlAccessibleObject

Docs.summary: Provides information about the control to accessibility client applications.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Windows Forms has accessibility support built in and provides information about your application that allows it to work with accessibility client applications. Examples of accessibility client applications are screen enlarger and reviewer utilities, voice input utilities, on-screen keyboards, alternative input devices, and keyboard enhancement utilities.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> class inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> class to provide information about the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control to accessibility client applications. Each class that represents a visual part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> - <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> - also contains a class that inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> to provide information about the containing class and perform actions on behalf of accessibility client applications.
There are instances when you will want to provide additional information, such as the name or description of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control, to accessibility client applications. There are two ways of providing this additional information. To provide limited accessibility information for existing controls, set the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleName%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDescription%2A> property values, which will be reported to accessibility client applications.
> [!NOTE] > You should change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDefaultActionDescription%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleRole%2A> property values only in rare situations, such as if you make a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> look like a list.
Occasionally, you might require more accessibility information or different accessibility actions to be included with your custom <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>. To customize accessibility, you can write your own class that derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject> classes and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method. For example, if you are writing a custom row header cell that implements unique custom actions, such as special hit testing within your cell, you should create a class that inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.DataGridViewRowHeaderCellAccessibleObject> class and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> exposes its data structure by using <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleRole> values to define the data table hierarchy. For more information on exposing data tables to Microsoft Active Accessibility, see "Exposing Data Tables through Microsoft Active Accessibility" in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject GetChild(int32 index) cil managed
Public Overrides Function GetChild (index As Integer) As AccessibleObject

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the child accessible object.
Docs.summary: Returns the child accessible object corresponding to the specified index.
Docs.returns: An that represents the child accessible object corresponding to the specified index.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChild%2A> method returns an accessible object for the row of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell> objects when <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.ColumnHeadersVisible%2A> is `true` and `index` is 0. If <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.ColumnHeadersVisible%2A> is `false` and `index` is 0, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChild%2A> returns an accessible object for the first <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance int32 GetChildCount() cil managed
Public Overrides Function GetChildCount () As Integer

Docs.summary: Returns the number of child objects belonging to an accessible object.
Docs.returns: The number of child objects belonging to the accessible object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChildCount%2A> method returns the number of visible rows in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView>, plus 1 for the column header row if it is visible and 1 for each visible scroll bar. If there are no columns in the control, this method always returns 0.

MemberSignature.Value: public override System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject HitTest (int x, int y);
.method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject HitTest(int32 x, int32 y) cil managed
Public Overrides Function HitTest (x As Integer, y As Integer) As AccessibleObject
public: override System::Windows::Forms::AccessibleObject ^ HitTest(int x, int y);

Docs.summary: Retrieves the child object at the specified screen coordinates.
Docs.returns: An that represents an object at the given screen coordinates, or if no object is at the specified location.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.HitTest%2A> method returns an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> that represents part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView>. If the object itself is at the specified location, this method returns the calling object. The following table describes what the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> represents.
|Area clicked|Object represented by accessible object| |------------------|---------------------------------------------| |Column header cell|<xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell>| |Row header cell|<xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>| |Cell|<xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>| |Scroll bar|<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject>|

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overrides ReadOnly Property Name As String
public: virtual property System::String ^ Name { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the accessible object name.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject Navigate(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation navigationDirection) cil managed
Public Overrides Function Navigate (navigationDirection As AccessibleNavigation) As AccessibleObject

Docs.returns: An that represents the object positioned at the specified value.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.FirstChild> value to get the first child accessible object of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject>, and use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.LastChild> to get the last child. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.Navigate%2A> method will return `null` for all other values of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation> enumeration.
